title: Does Einstein's Theory of relativity explain why c is invariant, or does it just explain how it affects our views of the nature of space and time? - Quora

response.answer_text: Viktor T. Toth answers: “No, it does not. The invariance of the vacuum speed of light follows from Maxwell’s equations, if one assumes that the physical properties of the vacuum (its electric permittivity and magnetic permeability) do not depend on the speed of the observer”. This is not quite true. In his special relativity paper, Einstein proves that c is invariant for all observers. Contrary to popular belief, Maxwell and Lorentz did not postulate that c is invariant for all observers. They postulated that c is constant and does not depend on the speed of its source. Einstein’s special theory of relativity is a principle theory, a heuristic system of two principles. First, Einstein generalized the Galilean principle of relativity and adopted the above Maxwellian (Lorentzian) postulate of light: The principle of relativity: The laws of physics are independent, whether these changes of state are referred to the one or the other of two systems of coordinates in uniform motion of translation. The postulate of the velocity of light: Any ray of light moves in the coordinate system K with the definite velocity c, independent of whether the ray is emitted by a moving or a body at rest. Or: The speed of light is constant and does not depend on the speed of its source. Einstein, however, was occupied with the contradiction between the Galilean principle of relativity and the constancy of the velocity of light in Maxwell's theory. In the special theory of relativity Einstein gave up the ether. Having renounced the ether and understanding that the laws of physics are the same with respect to all inertial systems (generalizing the Galilean principle of relativity), Einstein showed that his two principles (generalized principle of relativity and the postulate of the velocity of light) are actually compatible, from which it follows: The speed of light in vacuum is the same for all observers, regardless of their motion relative to the source. Thus, c is invariant. Neither Maxwell nor Lorentz formulated this principle! Thus, the two principles of Einstein’s special theory of relativity can now be formulated in the following form: The laws of nature are the same in all inertial reference frames. (The principle of relativity is valid for all reference frames).The speed of light in vacuum, as measured in any inertial reference frame, is c regardless of the motion of the light source relative to that reference frame.Einstein writes in the relativity paper: For we have not as yet furnished the proof that the principle of the constancy of the velocity of light is compatible with the principle of relativity. Einstein, “On the Electrodynamics of Moving Bodies” [German], Annalen Der Physik, 1905. Indeed, Einstein obtained the Lorentz transformations and then he proved that any ray of light, measured in one inertial system, is propagated with the velocity c if this is the case in any other system. According to the "light postulate" defined above, any ray of light moves in the coordinate system K with the definite velocity c, independent of whether the ray is emitted by a moving or a body at rest. In the Maxwell-Lorentz theory of the electron, this was indeed the case in a system at rest in the stationary ether, which was superfluous in Einstein's theory. Einstein, however, proved that light is also propagated with the definite velocity c as measured in the system k because he renounced the ether. Consider the equation of a spherical wave propagating with the velocity c in system K:  Transforming this equation with the aid of the equations of the Lorentz transformation gives (in the coordinates of the system k):  Einstein concludes his derivation by saying: The wave under consideration is also a spherical wave with velocity of propagation c when it is observed in the moving system. This demonstrates that our two fundamental principles are compatible. Einstein, “On the Electrodynamics of Moving Bodies” [German], Annalen Der Physik, 1905.

The Theory of Relativity does not explain why c is invariant, it merely assumes that and draws out its conclusions from there. However, that assumption is based on two pieces of evidence that show that a RELATIVE speed of light is impossible. Viktor T. Toth is only partially correct in stating that the invariance of the speed of light “follows” from Maxwell’s equations. Maxwell’s equations show that the speed of light is unaffected by motion of the source, meaning that the speed of light can not be increased or decreased and is not subject to a relative speed of light due to motion of the source. But what is lacking in Viktor’s discussion is that it does not “follow” from Maxwell’s equations that motion of an observer does not result in a relative speed of light. The motion of an observer ALSO has no effect on the relative speed of light “follows” from experiments to detect an ether, and more specifically an ether wind, such as the Michelson- Morley experiment. Maxwell’s equations indicate that the electromagnetic radiation moves as a wave, which is indicated by the lack of any relative speed of light due to motion of a source, and is EXACTLY how it works with sound waves. Sound is propagated as a wave, the speed of sound is medium dependent, and sound can not travel any faster or slower through the medium. BUT unlike Einstein’s invariance postulate, with sound, a motion of an OBSERVER relative to sound waves can create a relative speed of sound. So, IF light is a wave, then it requires a medium, therefore, experiments like the Michelson-Morley were an attempt to discover such a medium. According to these experiments, a relative speed of light was not found due to motion of an observer, therefore it was concluded these two basic assumptions: 1) an ether does not exist, and 2) a relative speed of light is not possible due to motion of an observer. Since motion of the source, nor motion of an observer can create a relative speed of light, then the speed of light is never relative and therefore invariant. No one knows why this is the case (and some like me do not think it is true it all) but this is the evidence that leads to the assumption. Based on this assumption, and assuming it is correct, then Einstein realized that since the speed of light is invariant, SOMETHING has to be variant, and in his theory it is TIME and SPACE that are capable of being altered. So in a way, it explains how it affects our notions of TIME and SPACE better than it explains the reason why the speed of light is invariant. Technically, Einstein’s second postulate is in opposition to Quantum because its behavior follows neither a particle (relative speed of light due to motion of source or observer), nor a wave (relative speed due to an observer, not due to a source). At best, it is “half-wave-like” since motion of the source does not affect the relative speed of light, which is the only characteristic Einstein’s postulate shares with sound. Since, Quantum assumes a wave-particle duality, then this indicates another disagreement between Quantum and Relativity.

So when our perception speed slows our brain needs to find the peak that has the wave*length* that fills our evolved need to see blue at 470 nm. As we blue shifted our original peak to be shorter and higher,in frequency our brain was slowing and inversely reversing the Doppler effect that we were causing by moving into light. Our own physical perception speed as well as our clocks and light measuring devices are all affected the same way. We all slide up and down the peaks to find the wave lengths are all tuned to. None of the measurements we make of the cosmos mean anything at all without considering the relativistic aspects. But no one has ever done this. Figured in where we are in the ranges of perception, aging, and contraction compared to other objects doing other frames. And it happens even to the level of my fingers moving faster than most of the rest of my body as I type this. Earthlings are not quite as sentient as they think they are. :) Or corpuscles, photons, duality, and light’s magical ability to ignore the laws of physics would never have been somehow seen as reasonable and accepted.. Cause theyre not. They’re make believe. IMHO

response.answer_text: I am going to make a bold statement, based on a couple of years of answering variants of this question . . . It does *not* matter what Einstein said or proved. Masses of people don’t trust it. Note that I said don’t trust, not don’t believe, though there are some of those too. They don’t trust it because they don’t trust the “logical” argument of it. It leaves out too much. People remember having been fooled in the past by similar arguments. They all require some assumption that might be questionable, etc. A second reason has to do with cooperation theory, and reciprocal cooperation games. If experts are trusted, they will take advantage of people. Not saying Einstein did, but he is not now alive defending this, and I think Einstein would likely by now have adopted a quantum field theory explanation. The reason I think that is that he kind of apologized in the London Times in 1919 for not having a constructive theory. Quantum field theory supposes that all excitations in quantum fields travel at the same speed. It does not matter what that speed is. But since the electromagnetic field is one of the quantum fields, it happens to be the speed of light. But it is not necessary to assume it is invariant. It is in fact not invariant if measured from an unchanging reference frame or point. But everything is made from excitations in quantum fields, including clocks and meter sticks. If you make a measurement, you are basing it on the speed things travel in quantum fields. All you can measure is a ratio of the speed you measure to the speed intrinsic to quantum fields. Therefore, no matter how the speed of quantum fields changes at your location (in gravitational fields it gets slow), you always get the same ratio. All you are doing is comparing the distance light travels, to the distance quantum excitations travel through your meter stick and clock, from one state configuration of the clock to another. If you don’t change clocks, or you calibrate any new clock based on the old one, you must therefore get the same value, making local c invariant. QED.

For Einstein, the “apple that fell on his head” was Michelson-Morley’s observation that the speed of light was constant no matter what the relative velocity of motion. That’s what set him thinking, and he had to reason out using “thought experiments” how it could be so, and thus came up with a new theoretical model in physics, along with the accompanying mathematics. In other words, the basic starting premise for Einstein’s relativity was, “Let us assume the speed of light is constant everywhere in the universe.” However, Einstein does not conclusively explain why the speed of light is that universal constant, nor how it is so precisely and universally regulated. We might say, while Einstein objected to quantum mechanics, “There must be hidden variables; God does not play dice”; he did not go on to explain the “hidden variables” in his own relativity theory, either the Special or the General theories. Having raised this challenge, I would venture to offer an explanation as to how and why the speed of light is so regulated and why it is central. Namely, we propose a “physical vacuum” underlying the quantum level of interaction. While the quantum wave manifests as a particle in the physical realm, the wave itself is not a physical entity, but resides and is coordinated or governed from the metaphysical realm as a rule-abiding system. “Time” itself is among the subjective, causal pillars of the physical realm, while residing in the metaphysical realm along with the natural laws and the physical constants. By definition, the core relational principle of time and space is centered upon the speed of light: The speed of light is defined as a constant of the value c, clocking out a precise period of time in traversing a unit of space, let us call it the “Planck length.” Then Einstein’s Special Theory of Relativity explains how space is distorted according to relative observers, in order that the lapse of time from one coordinate system appears differently to another, and concomitantly the measure of a unit of space is compressed, with the result that the speed of light is still the same. Likewise General Relativity explains how space is distorted by a gravitational field so that time runs slower while space is compressed. So how does that happen? A mechanism in the subjective, causal realm defines the “zero time line of simultaneity” based on the travel geodesic of the photon through space. Then a universal clocking mechanism of absolute precision operating holographically throughout the universe defines the absolute length of a unit of time based on the interval of space covered by a photon. So these three are fundamentally and intimately linked: interval in space-time, the photon as a quantum wave marking space and time, and the universal unit of lapse of time.

Does Einstein's Theory of relativity explain why c is invariant, or does it just explain how it affects our views of the nature of space and time? Lorentz, Maxwell, Newton. Einstein, Planck and others, all tried to explain the same thing; but what was that thing exactly? Galilei affirmed one thing that got my attention. This maximum energy resulted in a maximal “work” being done, meaning that it manifested at the maximal speed, which is “lightspeed”. This events constitutes all energy that will ever exist in our universe. It cannot be augmented nor diminished. All it can do is be transformed in another kind of energy. But most importantly, this energy is the exclusive “nature” of the “universal space”; in other words: the universe is simply and basically “energy”. Which means that the three dimensional space is simply and exclusively “energy” manifesting in all directions. Now, we have to agree that the “logic”, at the very base of the Big-bang notion, needs that everything starts at zero; be it energy, temperature or even time. So let’s use “time” starting at zero, when energy begins to accumulate until reaching its “maximum”, which was manifested at the Big-bang’s “first instant”, when “space” appeared (which cannot be at “time = zero” evidently). All this oblige us to consider the following geometric symbols:  This “10*-43 sec” was the “instant” of the Big-bang when “space” appeared. And this is how a geometric symbol describes it: 10*-43 sec after (T = 0) = Big-bang = total existing energy = lightspeed  The first “space volume” appeared as soon as all actual existing energy was manifested at the Big-bang’s “instant”. This energy had just attained its maximum, which, naturally, manifested at a maximal speed: lightspeed. Lightspeed, timewise, equals to “one present moment”; and that lightspeed “present moment” represents a “distance” of 10*-35 meter (it takes 10*-43 sec to travel 10*-35 meter at lightspeed). When the next “present moment” appeared, that “present moment” slid to a “past moment”, and lightspeed energy, kept manifesting in “all directions” producing additional “space volumes”:  We have, here, already the answer to the question asked: The red arrows represents “c” (lightspeed); and we can see by comparing both drawings that “c” is an “invariant” since, being surrounded by “nothingness”, it never encounters any “obstruction” to its manifesting “work”. As for the “space volume”, they are nothing more than “distances” of motion in all directions; in other words, they are simply outward oriented “energy”; which cannot be “matter” or “mass” since mass-energy provokes an orientation towards a “center point of gravity” instead of towards all directions. This also means that “mass-energy” hadn’t appear yet. So, yes, “c” is an invariant. But these “geometric symbols” of the “universal book”, tell us much more than that: 1: It tells us that “space” doesn’t expand by a factor of “2”, but by a factor of “3”; which makes the metrics of a “gravitational field” a lot greater than expected, and, that the “inverse square law” possesses a factor too “small” to be applied to a “gravitational field”. Because, as we see on the drawing, the first “present moment” of 10*-43 sec equals ONE basic volume, while the second “interval” is represented by THREE basic volumes; and the third interval would be represented by NINE basic volumes. And that explains why an observer always stands at the center of “universal time” (and “space”) seeing the “past” all around him whatever the direction he looks. 4: It also explains that when the universe was 13 billion years old, its observable diameter, possible to be “seen” by an observer, was 26 billion years (time), while its total diameter was 78 billion lightyears “space”. Galileo Galilei really possessed a great scientific mind.

In a broad sweeping way that glosses over much detail, invariant c is the axiom of SR as no explanation is in it. Then GR comes along next decade and says, well, gravitational fields do more than just keep us on the ground and moons and planets in orbit, they affect the paths of all objects moving in those fields, even light (EMR, photons). So c is not absolutely invariant in that context. There is gravitational red shift, of course, in which the frequency varies depending on vector relative to field center, and there is some support that even c the great invariant, is not absolutely invariant. But more interesting (for me) is the end of your question, how all these descriptions emanating from the general discourse of physics and cosmology, affects our views of the nature of space and time. There seems to be two views to be affected by these descriptions: space and time (spacetime) are tangible “things” with a flexible malleable geometry, somewhat resembling a chunk of latex rubber under stress forces, and, spacetime is a mathematical device. I might go even further and say that spacetime is a talking point in GR; the field equations do all the heavy lifting, and there’s no “spacetime” in these equations, just spacetime metrics, aka dimensions. There’s a good reason why they are called “field equations” and not “spacetime equations”. GR explains that mass generates gravitational fields, those fields have energy, that energy exerts a kind of pressure on objects moving in those fields. The effect is on the rate of actions occurring in the field. One action is spatial displacement (motion). The field is strongest at the surface of the agglomeration of mass generating the field. Below the surface and the field gets weaker as there is less and less mass below and more and more mass above. Above the surface, the field weakens by the square of the distance. These differences in the strength of the field is a pressure gradient; a mass object moving in that field has a side which is closer to the center of the field and a side further from the center. The greater the pressure, the slower the rate of action (motion), and it is this difference in time across the solid mass which steers the object into following what GR calls Riemannian geodesics. Geodesics appear curved to us observers because of the manner in which we visualize space, in Euclidean terms of flatness and straightness. It isn’t spacetime which is curved; it’s the paths of object moving in g-fields which are curved, steered by the time differential. Something similar occurs with EMR, but on a vastly different scale because EMR has no mass, only velocity and kinetic energy (momentum). Thus the geometry of the geodesics they follow is different than for mass objects, except perhaps in the extreme conditions of being close to a collapsed neutron star, then, according to what we’ve gleaned about those cosmic entities (so-called “black holes”) the gravity within the event horizon will make even EMR follow an orbit-like geodesic.

Most explanations of SR follow Einstein in giving a top-down derivation that treats the invariance of c as an axiom. But once you have the whole picture, a bottom-up explanation is available as well. It’s basically a combination of two things: To a first approximation, the speed of light is c in every frame SR because by procrustean methods you force it to be c. Every measurement frame in SR is laid out using Einstein synchronisation, which, give or take some interesting fine print, is tantamount to futzing with the synchronization of clocks until the one-way speed of light measured with those clocks comes out to be c. The fine print is that all ES does directly is to make the speed of light equal in any pair of opposite directions, say ±x. So if you try this stunt in a non-relativistic universe and you have an aether frame where light travels at ±c and you were expecting the velocities in a frame moving past at v to be +c-v and -c-v per the Galilean transformation, then ES will give a speed of [math]\mathrm{avg}(|+c-v|,|-c-v|)[/math]. And I write it that way because there’s a trick: the correct average for speeds is not [math]\mathrm{avg}(a,b)=(a+b)/2 \rightarrow (|+c-v|+|-c-v|)/2=((c-v)+(c+v))/2=c[/math]. Rather it’s [math]\mathrm{avg}(a,b) = 2/(1/a+1/b) \rightarrow c(1-v^2/c^2)[/math]. That’s because in a round-trip measurement, it’s the different times that add, and the time is in the denominator of the velocity ([math]v=x/t[/math]). Intuitively, if the frame is moving at c, light will take infinite time on the upstream leg, so the average round-trip velocity will be 0. Now - spoiler alert - that [math]1-v^2/c^2[/math] factor is the inverse square of the Lorentz factor, [math]\gamma(v)=1/\sqrt{1-v^2/c^2}[/math]. That is, if you try this stunt in a non-relativistic universe and a non-aether frame, you can make the two-way speed of light close to c, but you can’t make it exactly c - it will be slower by the LF squared. Actually it will be slower by up to the LF squared, depending on direction. For a transverse round-trip it will be slower by just one LF. And this is what the famous Michelson–Morley experiment - Wikipedia was looking for: it’s basically a comparison of the round-trip times in two arms at right-angles, and was hoping to see the difference between LF and LF^2. Notoriously however it didn’t see anything. So there must be new physics. Lorentz’s suggestion, which Einstein incorporated, is that the apparatus length contracts by LF in the longitudinal direction, cancelling half of the LF^2. And the other LF turns out to go away for both arms because any and all clocks in relativity are time dilated by one LF. (The MM experiment is deliberately insensitive to this, but you can confirm it with other experiments.) So forcing the speed of light to be the same in each direction by futzing with clocks is not as stupid as it sounds at first because Nature supplies the extra physics to mop up the discrepancies that you’d otherwise expect.

First, Maxwell recognized from his equations of electrodynamics (which have proved themselves to be consistent with all classical electric, magnetic and electromagnetic wave phenomena) that light is electromagnetic wave that travels with a velocity c =3.00x 10^8 m/s in vacuum. Then, Lorentz discovered that Maxwell’s equations of electrodynamics remain invariant (or, do not change at all) if space and time coordinates are changed in a specific way when described from two different coordinate frames that move with a constant relative velocity v between them. Finally, Einstein was the first to see that Lorentz’s transformation had a deep significance — it implied that the velocity of light in vacuum, c, must be a constant of nature and that space and time are not independent immutable absolutes but depend on one another. For example, ‘now’ here is not ‘now’ everywhere. His (special) theory of relativity is based on two axioms, one, that the laws of physics must look the same (be ‘covariant’) in all coordinate frames moving with a constant velocity v relative to one another, and two, that the velocity of light in vacuum, c, is a constant independent of the velocity of its (light’s) source. It’s predictions and explanations of physical phenomena have been validated in innumerable experiments without exception (barring gravitation, the domain of the general theory of relativity) since its inception more that a century ago. This is briefly why the constancy of the velocity of light c is both a postulate in the theory of relativity as well as an observed fact that changed our common sense view of the mutually independent and absolute space and time of Newtonian physics and explained their mutual dependency. [The general theory of relativity or gravitation affects this departure of the ‘common sense’ view of the absolute nature of space and time, even further.]

response.answer_text: The question is, why wouldn’t it be. To quote Einstein from his little book from Princeton University Press, The Meaning of Relativity, “The speed of light is something we know best about”. Einstein wondered, when looking at Maxwell’s Equations of Electromagnetism; what was the speed of light in these wave equations relative to? Some absolute rest frame? Was there such a thing as an absolutely stationary frame of reference in a void? How would you measure it or determine it with nothing there to compare it’s (or your) motion to? All you could know is whether you are at rest relative to the ground, the earth, or if in a satellite; possibly that of the sun or distant visible stars. That’s not ABSOLUTE rest, it’s still a rest relative to something else. But our solar system too moves relative to the center of our galaxy; or the movement of our galaxy relative to our super cluster or to some vast galactic centre for a collection of neighbouring galaxies…..and so on. There’s no way to pin down some absolute rest frame. It is interesting to note that the Maxwell equations do not obey the old Newtonian or Galilean ideas of relativity; relative motion and absolute passage of time. Lorentz first picked up on this but his ideas, though yielding correct transformation equations between inertial observers, were wrong. Einstein arrived at the same transformation equations just from the constancy of the speed of light and that all observers must agree on the laws of physics; after all, we all occupy the same objective universe. So Einstein stated that such an absolute frame could not exist as it could not be measured. He then, therefore, dispensed immediately with this notion of a luminiferous aether. Why have a ‘fluid’ that, as Einstein stated, “…acts on but cannot be acted upon..”, this aether demanding itself to be the contender for this ‘absolute rest’ frame yet it cannot be measured? If it existed, it would have to be at variance with the fundamental ideas of cause and effect or forces and reactions as so splendidly stated by Newton earlier; for it can have only an effect yet no cause; an action yet offer no reaction. Therefore, since light, at least, travels through a vacuum, it cannot have it’s speed measured in relation to some third party; namely an absolute rest frame; only by some party involved in doing the observation on the speed of light at that moment, namely US! So without an absolute rest frame, there’s no frame that the speed ‘C’ has it’s particular value for over and above any other frame of reference, again - for instance; there’s just US! The right conclusion then MUST BE that the speed of light should be the same for any (or ALL) observers then. I think that is Einstein’s reasoning as best I’ve been able to glean it. This is just a personal reflection though.

response.answer_text: Firstly, c is not invariant. The theory of relativity doesn't explain why c is invariant. It's built on the postulate that light speed is a constant. Let me give you a simple analogy. Car A is traveling at 50 km/h, while car B is traveling at 60 km/h. Now we can say that in 3 hours, car A travels 150 km and car B travels 180 km. Or, we can say that car A takes 6 hours to travel 300 km and car B takes 5 hours to travel 300 km. Both statements are true. The difference is that in the first example we make time a constant and in the second case we make distance a constant. Note, it doesn't mean that time is constant. It doesn't prove that time is constant. Einstein created a theory involving 3 variables and made one of them a constant. He chose, “the speed of light”. Personally, I would have made “distance” a constant and the “speed of light” relative, but that's just me. Why do things the easy way? If time is relative, it follows that speed is relative. You need a common denominator to calculate distance travelled with non-invariant temporal velocity. Something which is a universal constant.

No, it does not. The invariance of the vacuum speed of light follows from Maxwell’s equations, if one assumes that the physical properties of the vacuum (its electric permittivity and magnetic permeability) do not depend on the speed of the observer. Special relativity elevates this concept to a postulate, and alters our understanding of space and time as a consequence. In the modern viewpoint, though relativity theory is taken to be extremely thoroughly confirmed through a large variety of experiments and observations (both relativity theory itself and theories derived from, or relying on it) it is not taken for granted that light actually travels at the invariant speed of special relativity, i.e., what we call the vacuum speed of light. There is, after all, a perfectly sensible field theory alternative to Maxwell’s, Proca theory, otherwise known as massive electromagnetism, in which light always travels slower than the invariant speed. So whether or not electromagnetism is truly massless now becomes a question subject to observational verification. This includes both laboratory tests and astrophysical/astronomical observations that place ever more stringent upper limits on what the maximum rest mass of a photon can be. These limits are very small, so it is generally assumed that the photon is truly massless but, as I said, it is not taken for granted.  I thank my generous supporters on Patreon. If you like my answers, please consider joining them.

Timotheos J Smüdtski: You ask: Does Einstein's Theory of relativity explain why c is invariant, or does it just explain how it affects our views of the nature of space and time? The way Einstein formulated his 1905 paper, the invariance of c was stipulated as a postulate: so, an assumption. (That postulate was “inspired” by Maxwell’s equations of electromagnetism [EM].) However, the geometric formulation of Special Relativity (SR), inspired by Minkowski’s reformulation (and General Relativity [GR], since SR is really a special, rigidly flat case of GR) yields an invariant speed, without any postulate beyond the scalar-product with one eigenvalue of the opposite sign of the other three. This matches SR, with only a choice of units bringing this invariant speed to be “c”. From this formulation, it is straightforward to derive a U(1) field that matches EM. (It’s not like this is any sort of “revelation”. Such has been known for a very long time, from SR.) Yes. This is but a reformulation of SR and EM. Nothing truly new. Just a different way of looking at such.

response.answer_text: From a layman's point of view: When Maxwell got his famous equations, he had to have a constant c which had dimensions of [Length]/[Time]. This was a huge number and Maxwell rightly concluded that it was velocity of light in vacuum. Now the question: Velocity relative to what? It was thought that it is relative to an invisible fluid called Ether which filled space. Many attempts were made to determine the properties of Ether, but were unsuccessful. The most famous experiment was Michelson-Morley experiment, which proved beyond doubt that there was no effect of Ether or rather existence of Ether was not possible. In the explanation of this, Einstein made a simple assumption that c is an absolute constant. Lo and behold, a highly logical theory with rock solid consistency was born.
